The Constitution makers chose indirect election for the President of India because it is in harmony with the parliamentary system of government envisaged in the Constitution, where the President is only a nominal executive and the real powers are vested in the council of ministers headed by the prime minister. Direct election of the President would have been very costly and time-consuming due to the vast size of the electorate, and it would have been unwarranted keeping in view that the President is only a symbolic head.

answer: B) The doctrine that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution
explanation: The doctrine of basic structure of the Constitution was laid down by the Supreme Court in the Kesavananda Bharati case and reaffirmed in subsequent cases. It states that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution, which means that the Parliament cannot abridge or take away a Fundamental Right that forms a part of the 'basic structure' of the Constitution.
The Doctrine of Severability is applied by the Supreme Court while interpreting the constitution to ensure that a law is not declared unconstitutional in its entirety.
